content: The "Fair Access to Infertility Treatment and Hope Act of 2000" requires coverage for infertility benefits under the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974. Infertility affects millions of men and women, is treatable, and only a quarter of health plans cover infertility services. The "Fair Access to Infertility Treatment and Hope Act of 2000" mandates coverage for infertility benefits, including diagnostic testing, drug therapy, artificial insemination, and in vitro fertilization among other treatments. The "Fair Access to Infertility Treatment and Hope Act of 2000" mandates coverage for infertility benefits, including diagnostic testing, drug therapy, artificial insemination, and in vitro fertilization. Coverage for in vitro fertilization procedures may be limited to 4 completed embryo transfers, with additional transfers required if a live birth occurs. Coverage is provided if other infertility treatments have been unsuccessful. The "Fair Access to Infertility Treatment and Hope Act of 2000" requires group health plans to cover costly medically appropriate infertility treatments performed at approved medical facilities. Prohibitions include denying coverage based on the use of covered services and providing monetary incentives. The "Fair Access to Infertility Treatment and Hope Act of 2000" prohibits offering monetary incentives to individuals to accept less than minimum protections or to healthcare professionals to withhold services. Group health plans can still impose deductibles and cost-sharing for services covered under the act. The "Fair Access to Infertility Treatment and Hope Act of 2000" prohibits offering incentives to individuals or healthcare professionals to compromise on minimum protections. Group health plans can impose deductibles and cost-sharing for covered services, with limitations on experimental or investigational treatments. The "Fair Access to Infertility Treatment and Hope Act of 2000" includes limitations on the type of healthcare professionals that can provide treatments. The act also requires notice under group health plans for any modifications, with a deadline of 60 days after the first plan year in which the requirements apply. Sec. 714 requires coverage for infertility benefits for federal employees' health plans starting from January 1, 2001. Additionally, the Public Health Service Act is amended to include required coverage for infertility benefits under SEC. 2707. The provision mandates coverage for infertility benefits in group health plans, including diagnostic testing, drug therapy, artificial insemination, and in vitro fertilization procedures. Coverage of in vitro fertilization procedures may be limited to 4 completed embryo transfers, with additional transfers required if a live birth occurs. This coverage is provided if other infertility treatments have been unsuccessful in achieving a successful pregnancy. The text chunk discusses the coverage of costly medically appropriate infertility treatments, with procedures needing to be performed at approved medical facilities. It also prohibits group health plans from denying coverage based on an individual's use of covered services. The text prohibits monetary incentives to individuals to accept less coverage or to healthcare professionals to withhold services. It clarifies that deductibles and cost-sharing can still be imposed by group health plans. The text prohibits greater deductibles or cost-sharing for certain services under the plan. It also requires coverage of experimental treatments, unless coverage is provided for other experimental services. The text outlines limitations on health care professionals providing treatments, and requirements for notice under group health plans. Amendments are made to Part B of title XXVII of the Public Health Service Act. The provisions require coverage for infertility benefits in health insurance plans offered in the individual market, similar to coverage in group health plans. Effective January 1, 2001, these amendments apply to health insurance coverage for infertility benefits. Additionally, federal employees' health benefits plans are also required to cover infertility benefits. Infertility benefits, including diagnostic testing and various treatments, are now required to be included in health insurance plans under federal law. This coverage extends to federal employees' health benefits plans as well. Under federal law, health insurance plans must cover infertility treatments, including intra-fallopian tube transfer and other medically indicated procedures. These treatments are limited to 4 completed embryo transfers, with 2 additional transfers allowed if a live birth occurs. The procedures are provided if other less costly treatments have been unsuccessful and are performed at approved medical facilities. The amendments made by this section apply to contract years beginning on or after January 1, 2001.
